channel.title: As we see it: Vietnam '68
channel.description:
A series of appearances of noted spokesman presenting their various views on the war in Vietnam, conducted over a period of five weeks on the campus of Miami University in Oxford, Ohio, under the sponsorship of the Miami University Student Senate.

An online collection of early educational public radio content from the National Association of Educational Broadcasters (NAEB).

item.title: Dr. Walter Judd, Part 2
item.description: Dr. Walter Judd, a former U.S. Congressman and delegate to the General Assembly of the United Nations; also a former medical missionary in mainland China, makes the case of the Vietnam War as a watershed in the U.S.' willingness to use force to respond to the spread of Communism.
item.dc:creator: Miami University (Oxford, Ohio)
item.dc:subject: World Politics

item.title: Harrison Salisbury/Robert Scalapino, Part 2
item.description: A debate between Harrison Salisbury, a Pulitzer Prize winning journalist for the New York Times, and Robert Scalapino, a member of the faculty at the University of California, Berkeley, on the issue of continuing the United States military action in Vietnam.
item.dc:creator: Miami University (Oxford, Ohio)
item.dc:subject: War & Civil Defense

item.title: Dr. William A. Williams, Part 1
item.description: Dr. William A. Williams, professor of history at the University of Wisconsin and author of The Great Evasion, redefined the war in Vietnam as a symptom, rather than an issue, representing the death of the our image of ourselves as Americans and our role in the world.
item.dc:creator: Miami University (Oxford, Ohio)
item.dc:subject: War & Civil Defense

item.title: Dr. Howard Zinn, Part 2
item.description: Dr. Howard Zinn, associate professor of government at Boston University and former director, Non-Western Studies Program, Atlanta University, discusses the symbolic roots of warfare, declaring the Vietnam War as war at its worst, a war "without any visible, understandable, tangible social reason."
item.dc:creator: Miami University (Oxford, Ohio)
item.dc:subject: War & Civil Defense

item.title: Tran Van Dinh, Part 2
item.description: A speech by Trần Văn Dĩnh, former ambassador from South Vietnam to the U.S. and chief Washington correspondent for The Saigon Post, who argues that the U.S. cannot win in Vietnam because its military force doesn't match the type of war it is fighting.
item.dc:creator: Miami University (Oxford, Ohio)
item.dc:subject: War & Civil Defense

item.title: Rowland Evans/Robert Novak, Part 1
item.description: Columnists Rowland Evans and Robert Novak assessed the current state of the war in Vietnam and the political implications for the upcoming presidential election, including the public weariness over the war and the candidacy of Democrat Eugene McCarthy.
item.dc:creator: Miami University (Oxford, Ohio)
item.dc:subject: World Politics

item.title: Gen. Maxwell Taylor/Roger Hilsman, Part 1
item.description: Gen. Maxwell Taylor, former chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff and ambassador to South Vietnam, and Roger Hilsman, special advisor to Presidents Kennedy and Johnson, offered different opinions about nature of the Vietnam conflict and the continued use of military force.
item.dc:creator: Miami University (Oxford, Ohio)
item.dc:subject: War & Civil Defense

item.title: Dr. William A. Williams, Part 2
item.description: Dr. William A. Williams, professor of history at the University of Wisconsin and author of The Great Evasion, redefined the war in Vietnam as a symptom, rather than an issue, representing the death of the our image of ourselves as Americans and our role in the world.
item.dc:creator: Miami University (Oxford, Ohio)
item.dc:subject: War & Civil Defense

item.description: Dr. Howard Zinn, associate professor of government at Boston University and former director, Non-Western Studies Program, Atlanta University, discusses the symbolic roots of warfare, declaring the Vietnam War as war at its worst, a war "without any visible, understandable, tangible social reason."
item.dc:creator: Miami University (Oxford, Ohio)
item.dc:subject: War & Civil Defense

item.dc:creator: Miami University (Oxford, Ohio)
item.dc:subject: World Politics

item.title: Rowland Evans/Robert Novak, Part 2
item.description: Columnists Rowland Evans and Robert Novak
item.dc:creator: Miami University (Oxford, Ohio)
item.dc:subject: World Politics

item.title: Tran Van Dinh, Part 1
item.description: A speech by Trần Văn Dĩnh, former ambassador from South Vietnam to the U.S. and chief Washington correspondent for The Saigon Post, who argues that the U.S. cannot win in Vietnam because its military force doesn't match the type of war it is fighting.
item.dc:creator: Miami University (Oxford, Ohio)
item.dc:subject: War & Civil Defense

item.title: Dr. John Lewis, Part 1
item.description: Dr. John Lewis of Cornell University, co-author of The United States and Vietnam, discusses the evolution of Chinese policy towards the Vietnam War and North Vietnam's strategy in the aftermath of the Tet Offensive.
item.dc:creator: Miami University (Oxford, Ohio)
item.dc:subject: War & Civil Defense

item.title: Gen. Maxwell Taylor/Roger Hilsman, Part 2
item.description: Gen. Maxwell Taylor, former chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff and ambassador to South Vietnam, and Roger Hilsman, special advisor to Presidents Kennedy and Johnson, offered different opinions about nature of the Vietnam conflict and the continued use of military force.
item.dc:creator: Miami University (Oxford, Ohio)
item.dc:subject: War & Civil Defense

item.title: Dr. John Lewis, Part 2
item.description: Dr. John Lewis of Cornell University, co-author of The United States and Vietnam, discusses the evolution of Chinese policy towards the Vietnam War and North Vietnam's strategy in the aftermath of the Tet Offensive.
item.dc:creator: Miami University (Oxford, Ohio)
item.dc:subject: War & Civil Defense

item.title: David Halberstam, Part 1
item.description: A speech by David Halberstam, the Pulitzer Prize-winning Vietnam correspondent for The New York Times and author of The Making of a Quagmire and One Very Hot Day, who cites the recent Tet Offensive as evidence that the United States cannot win the Vietnam War.
item.dc:creator: Miami University (Oxford, Ohio)
item.dc:subject: War & Civil Defense

item.title: David Halberstam, Part 2
item.description: A speech by David Halberstam, the Pulitzer Prize-winning Vietnam correspondent for The New York Times and author of The Making of a Quagmire and One Very Hot Day, who cites the recent Tet Offensive as evidence that the United States could not win the Vietnam War.
item.dc:creator: Miami University (Oxford, Ohio)
item.dc:subject: War & Civil Defense

item.title: Harrison Salisbury/Robert Scalapino, Part 1
item.description: A debate between Harrison Salisbury, a Pulitzer Prize winning journalist for the New York Times, and Robert Scalapino, a member of the faculty at the University of California, Berkeley, on the issue of continuing the United States military action in Vietnam.
item.dc:creator: Miami University (Oxford, Ohio)
item.dc:subject: War & Civil Defense

item.title: Dr. George M. Kahin, Part 1
item.description: Dr. George M. Kahin, director of the Southeast Asia Project at Cornell University and recent co-author of a book entitled The United States and Vietnam, argues that the political myths nurtured by the current administration has ensured that public cannot be expected to accept the minimum concessions necessary to achieve a compromise--which is the essential basis for any negotiated settlement in the region.
item.dc:creator: Miami University (Oxford, Ohio)
item.dc:subject: World Politics

item.title: Dr. George M. Kahin, Part 2
item.description: Dr. George M. Kahin, director of the Southeast Asia Project at Cornell University and recent co-author of a book entitled The United States and Vietnam, argues that the political myths nurtured by the current administration has ensured that public cannot be expected to accept the minimum concessions necessary to achieve a compromise--which is the essential basis for any negotiated settlement in the region.
